standard_metadata.standard_description: Understand that patterns of association can also be seen in bivariate categorical data by displaying frequencies and relative frequencies in a two-way table. Construct and interpret a two-way table summarizing data on two categorical variables collected from the same subjects. Use relative frequencies calculated for rows or columns to describe possible association between the two variables.

question.content: Researchers once surveyed college students on their Facebook use. The following two-way table displays data for the  sample of students who responded to the survey.  **How many students in the survey were in the age category of $18$ to $22?$**   students  Age | Uses Facebook | Does not use Facebook - | :-: |:-: $18$ to $22$ | $78$ | $4$ $23\,\text{+}$ | $70$ | $67$  [//]: # (A. Karpinski and A. Duberstein, “A description of Facebook use and academic performance among undergraduate and graduate students,” paper presented at the American Educational Research Association annual meeting, April 2009. Thanks to Aryn Karpinski for providing us with some original data from the study.)

hints.content: To find how many students in the survey were in the age category of $18$ to $22,$ we can add to find the total number of students in that row.
Age | Uses Facebook | Does not use Facebook | TOTAL - | :-: |:-: |:-: $18$ to $22$ | $\blueD{78}$ | $\blueD{4}$ | $\blueD{82}$ $23\,\text{+}$ | $70$ | $67$ | $137$ **TOTAL** | $148$ | $71$ | $219$
There were $82$ students in the survey in the age category of $18$ to $22$.

question.content: Researchers once surveyed college students on their Facebook use. The following two-way table displays data for the  sample of students who responded to the survey.  **How many students in the survey responded that they use Facebook?**   students  Age | Uses Facebook | Does not use Facebook - | :-: |:-: $18$ to $22$ | $78$ | $4$ $23\,\text{+}$ | $70$ | $67$  [//]: # (A. Karpinski and A. Duberstein, “A description of Facebook use and academic performance among undergraduate and graduate students,” paper presented at the American Educational Research Association annual meeting, April 2009. Thanks to Aryn Karpinski for providing us with some original data from the study.)

hints.content: To find how many students in the survey responded that they use Facebook, we can add to find the total number of students in that column.
Age | Uses Facebook | Does not use Facebook | TOTAL - | :-: |:-: |:-: $18$ to $22$ | $\blueD{78}$ | $4$ | $82$ $23\,\text{+}$ | $\blueD{70}$ | $67$ | $137$ **TOTAL** | $\blueD{148}$ | $71$ | $219$
There were $148$ students in the survey that responded that they used Facebook.

question.content: Researchers once surveyed college students on their Facebook use. The following two-way table displays data for the  sample of students who responded to the survey.  **How many $18$ to $22$ year old students in the survey responded that they use Facebook?**   students  Age | Uses Facebook | Does not use Facebook - | :-: |:-: $18$ to $22$ | $78$ | $4$ $23\,\text{+}$ | $70$ | $67$  [//]: # (A. Karpinski and A. Duberstein, “A description of Facebook use and academic performance among undergraduate and graduate students,” paper presented at the American Educational Research Association annual meeting, April 2009. Thanks to Aryn Karpinski for providing us with some original data from the study.)

hints.content: To find how many $18$ to $22$ year old students in the survey responded that they use Facebook, we look for the count in the table that corresponds to both "$18$ to $22$" and "uses Facebook".
Age | Uses Facebook | Does not use Facebook - | :-: |:-: $18$ to $22$ | $\blueD{78}$ | $4$ $23\,\text{+}$ | $70$ | $67$
There were $78$ students aged $18$ to $22$ years old  in the survey who responded that they use Facebook

question.content: Researchers once surveyed students on which superpower they would most like to have. The following two-way table displays data for the  sample of students who responded to the survey.  **How many students in the survey chose to fly as their superpower?**   students  Superpower | Male | Female - | :-: |:-: Flying | $26$ | $12$ Invisibility | $14$ | $32$ Other | $10$ | $8$

hints.content: To find how many students in the survey chose to fly as their superpower, we can add to find the total number of students in that row.
Superpower | Male | Female | TOTAL - | :-: |:-: |:-: | Flying | $\blueD{26}$ | $\blueD{12}$ | $\blueD{38}$ Invisibility | $14$ | $32$ | $46$ Other | $10$ | $8$ | $18$ **TOTAL** | $50$ | $52$ | $102$
There were $38$ students in the survey who chose to fly as their superpower.

question.content: A university surveyed its students on their opinions of campus housing. The following two-way table displays data for the sample of $200$ students who responded to the survey.  **How many students in this sample were female?**   students  Gender | Positive opinion | Negative opinion | Neutral opinion - | :-: |:-: | :-: Male | $40$ | $36$ | $14$  Female | $42$ | $56$ | $12$

hints.content: To find how many students in this sample were female, we can add to find the total number of students in that row.

Gender | Positive opinion | Negative opinion | Neutral opinion | TOTAL - | :-: |:-: | :-: | :-: Male | $40$ | $36$ | $14$ | $90$ Female | $\blueD{42}$ | $\blueD{56}$ | $\blueD{12}$ | $\blueD{110}$ **TOTAL** | $82$ | $92$ | $26$ | $200$
There were $110$ female students in this sample.

question.content: Researchers surveyed recent graduates of two different universities about their income. The following two-way table displays data for the  sample of graduates who responded to the survey.  **How many graduates in the sample had an income of $\$40\text{,}000$ and over?**   graduates  Income | University A | University B - | :-: |:-: |:-: | Under $\$20\text{,}000$ | $35$ | $40$  $\$20\text{,}000$ to $\$39\text{,}999$ | $90$ | $63$  $\$40\text{,}000$ and over| $35$ | $37$

hints.content: To find how many graduates in the sample had an income of $\$40\text{,}000$ and over, we can add to find the total number of graduates in that row.
There were $72$ graduates in the sample that had an income of  $\$40\text{,}000$ and over.

question.content: Students were surveyed about their preference between dogs and cats. The following two-way table displays data for the  sample of students who responded to the survey.  **How many students in the sample prefer dogs?**   students    Preference | Male | Female - | :-: |:-: |:-: | Prefers dogs | $36$ | $20$ Prefers cats | $10$ | $26$ No preference | $2$ | $6$

hints.content: To find how many students in the sample prefer dogs, we can add to find the total number of students in that row.

Preference | Male | Female | TOTAL - | :-: |:-: |:-: | Prefers dogs | $\blueD{36}$ | $\blueD{20}$ | $\blueD{56}$ Prefers cats | $10$ | $26$ | $36$ No preference | $2$ | $6$ | $8$ **TOTAL** | $48$ | $52$ | $100$
There were $56$ students in the sample who preferred dogs.

question.content: Teams in the National Football League in America are divided into two conferences: the AFC and the NFC. Some teams have animals as their mascots, and others do not. The following two-way table displays this data.  **How many teams have an animal mascot?**   teams    Mascot | AFC | NFC  - | :-: |:-: |:-: | Animal | $7$ | $8$  Non-animal | $9$ | $8$

hints.content: To find how many teams have an animal mascot, we can add to find the total number of teams in that row.
Mascot | AFC | NFC | TOTAL - | :-: |:-: |:-: | Animal | $\blueD7$ | $\blueD8$ | $\blueD{15}$ Non-animal | $9$ | $8$ | $17$ **TOTAL** | $16$ | $16$ | $32$
There are $15$ teams that have an animal mascot.
